Award.AwardTitle: Stochastic Topology and Topological Statistical Mechanics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stochastic topology is the study of random shapes, and topological statistical mechanics is the study of how complicated shapes change as some parameter, such as pressure or entropy, varies. This work involves the intersection of several mathematical disciplines, including topology, geometry, and combinatorics. It also has applications outside of mathematics. Stochastic topology provides a well-posed null hypothesis and for the emerging area of topological data analysis. Topological statistical mechanics endeavors to find topological underpinnings of different phases of matter. The broader impacts of this project are focused on research training of PhD students, and to prepare them for careers in academia, data science, and industry.

As part of this project, the PI will investigate new models of random simplicial complex, including random hypertrees. The fundamental group of a random 2-dimensional hypertree is an interesting model of random group, and one of the goals of the project is to prove that this group has Kazhdan's property (T) with high probability. It is an open-ended question whether these random hypertrees have a scaling limit; such a limit which would be higher-dimensional analogue of Aldous's continuum random tree. The PI will also investigate complicated configuration spaces, such as configuration spaces of hard disks or squares. These are interesting from the point of view of physics, since they represent the energy landscape for a hard-spheres system. Identifying the regimes where homology is trivial, nontrivial, or isomorphic to the ambient to the configuration space of points is a major part of the project, as are the asymptotic rate of growth of the Betti numbers as the number of particles tends to infinity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was to support research of PI Matthew Kahlein stochastic topology and topological statistical mechanics. Stochastic topology is the study of random shapes. Topological statistical mechanics is the study of phases spaces or energy landscapes of interacting particles systems, such as a hard spheres gas. In this fields, one is often interested in asymptotic behavior as some parameter tends to infinity. Another common theme is "phase transitions", where there is a drastic change in the qualitative behavior of a system with only a small variation of some underlying parameter. 
Intellectual Merit. Some of the research highlights that were supported by this award are as follows. Kahle and Newman initiated the topological study of random 2-dimensional hypertrees. Alpert, Bauer, Kahle, MacPherson, and Spendlove, studied configuration spaces of ordered hard squares in a rectangle. They gave some necessary conditions and some sufficient conditions for homology to be nontrivial  In a followup paper, Alpert, Kahle, MacPherson studied the rate of growth of the Betti numbers for these spaces, showing that the Betti numbers grow factorially fast in the number of particles. Ababneh and Kahle studied maximally persistent cycles in persistent homology of random clique complexes, showing that cycles persist for much longer than in the random geometric complexes studied earlier. Duncan, Kahle, and Schweinhart studied plaquette percolation with k-dimensional plaquettes in a d-dimensional torus. The main result is that in middle dimension, there is a sharp transition for giant cycles appearing at critical probability 1/2.
Broader Impacts. The broader impacts of this proposal were focused on mentoring graduate students. Over the course of this award, the PI graduated six PhD students. Some have gone on to reseach postdoc positions, and some have gone on to positions in industry. The PI also developed some new curriculum, teaching a graduate topics course on "random graphs and cell complexes", perhaps the first course of its kind. The research supported by this award has been disseminated widely. All the papers are available on the arXiv and on the PI's webpage, and the PI has given a number of talks at conferences and seminars.
